conversations.content: The Prince of Twilight: Part One
In a village on the edge of Grastaea lived two friends: a boy and a young dragon. Their heroes were Alberia's royal family and the dragons to whom they were pactbound.
The young dragon, a daydreamer with a tendency to show off, told the boy countless fantasies—among them a tale that he was known as the ＂prince of twilight.＂
...And that he was part of an immortal cursed dragon's soul, reborn from eternal darkness.
...And that Grastaea would be plunged into chaos when his true power awoke, which is why he'd been trapped in a small body in order to suppress his abilities.
Impressed by the young dragon's stories, the boy started to dream up a fitting legend for himself.
Using an iron pot for a crown, he claimed to be a reincarnation of Alberius the Founder—which meant he and his dragon friend had been inseparable even in their past lives.
They passed the days playing heroes in a secret fort they had built deep in the mountains.
The boy and the dragon told their stories to the villagers, who listened with patient smiles on their faces. They were charmed by the children's silly make-believe.
Travelers who happened to overhear, however, took it differently. Half convinced by what they heard, they brought rumors of the boy and the dragon to neighboring towns.
An empty throne had recently caused concern over the dynasty's collapse, and rumors of the last king's illegitimate children launched people into a frenzied search for his heir.
Many claimed to be the king's illegitimate child, of course—but there was only one with a dragon.
A nefarious group of kidnappers set their sights on the boy. They didn't care about the royal bloodline—only that they could ransom him for a handsome sum.
And so the kidnappers came to the village. The boy and the dragon, lost in their daydreams of heroism, had no reason to suspect they were in great danger.
The Prince of Twilight: Part Two
Having heard rumors of the boy with a dragon, a group of kidnappers came to the village. They found their secret fort at once and made off with the child.
The young dragon came flying at the sound of the boy's pathetic cries. ＂Get your filthy hands off of him!＂ he cried as courage flowed through his veins.
＂Oy, I never seen a dragon before!＂ snarled one of the kidnappers. ＂Didn't know they were so tiny. And look how it's shakin'! Ya scared'a humans, little dragon?＂
The dragon was, in truth, terrified, but he swallowed his fear and said, ＂Only fools dare set foot into the prince of twilight's domain.＂
＂I am the cursed dragon reborn. I can call forth an army of undead with but a word.＂
＂They eat the souls of the living! They'll bang their swords against their shields and grin their skeletal sneer as they bring you back to the underworld as trophies!＂
＂Cor!＂ cried a thug. ＂Y-Yer bluffin'!＂  ＂Am I?＂ replied the dragon.
The dragon and the kidnappers locked gazes. Then one of the kidnappers stepped on the royal crown—the iron pot—as it lay upon the ground.
CLANG! CLANG! CLANG! The kidnappers jumped into the air at the cacophony, then skittered away like the rats they were.
Out from the cart they'd left behind came all the other children they had stolen, who shouted and whooped for joy. They were free!
And that is how the boy and the dragon became real-life heroes.
